bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, March 23, 1942

div1.p: Wood returns material, which Hench had loaned to her, and discusses her manuscript. The publication delay permits her to do more research on Lazear. Wood comments on a Reed family legend that is almost certainly apocryphal.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, March 23, 1942

opener.dateline:
1338 19th St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
March 23, 1942

div1.p:
I'm sending you today by insured express the material you
so kindly lent me - so long ago. I checked it against the
list you made out at the time, and believe that I've re-
turned everything. I sent also the Senate Document. If I
need one later when I do some more checking I can probably
find one in some medical library in Philadelphia. I in-
cluded copies of a couple of letters from Reed to his father,
copies of which Alice Reed let me have. They aren't of any
value, just indicate that he had developed a little geneol-
ogical interest. Also I sent a letter I received from Dr.
William Howard, which I thought you might like to have for
your collection. It is a very nice and sweet letter
about Reed, and since it is from a rather important man I
thought it might interest you.

Now that publication has been pushed off until Fall, I'll
have a chance to give Lazear more credit than I did. I
can't help thinking that the rest of the doctors on the
board were practically blind to take no interest in the
mosquito theory when he was probably pushing it all the
time in conversations.

Thank you for your sketch of the course of the Quemados epi-
demic. I shan't of course use it except for reference - my
own, I mean.

The Register of Medical Officers you refer to must be what
I saw, too. Big books, kept in longhand, accounting for all
the orders and moves of each medical officer from year to
year? I've looked up Reed's from start to finish. One thing
of interest that I found is that the family legend about the
trip from Camp Apache to the Union Pacific tracks - 700 miles,
27 days and all the rest of it, - is almost certainly apochry-
phal. He was exactly two weeks getting from Apache to Rich-
mond, where he went on leave. There's even a letter in his own
hand dated May 27th (he started out on the 10th) from Richmond
asking for an extension of his leave. I don't doubt that at
one time or another he took such a trip, but I'm pretty sure
it wasn't then, especially since there was no sense on earth
in going out such a hard way when the Santa Fe Trail was com-
paratively easy.

I'm ashamed to say that I've never written to Mrs. Lazear, but
now that I have this unexpected breathing space I'm going to.
It is a little hard to allow how much of a hero Lazear was
without making Reed look a bit dumb, I think.

From April 1st on my address will be: 230 South 19th St.,
Philadelphia. As you may judge, we found a place to live.
It is on Rittenhouse Square, in a surprisingly ugly yellow
brick mansion, with red sandstone trim, now converted into
apartments. Since it is directly across the square from the
SEC Crosby will have no transportation problems.

I'll let you know from time to time of the progress of my
confection through the publisher, and shall also let you see
the revisions I make about Lazear. And of course I'll send
you one the minute it comes out.
